newsitem.title: POLAND: FEATURE - Pope visits Poland torn by rows over religion.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Pope visits Poland torn by rows over religion.

text.p: Pope John Paul II, who begins an 11-day pilgrimage to his native Poland on Saturday, lands in the midst of a domestic political battle centred in large part on the role of the Roman Catholic Church.

The trip falls during campaigning for a general election due later this year when rightist opposition parties led by the pro-Catholic Solidarity trade union hope to supplant the secular-minded ex-communists now in government.
The Polish Episcopate's General Secretary, Bishop Tadeusz Pieronek, said last month: "The Holy Father will not involve himself in our political debate."

That is more easily said than done. For Solidarity Election Action (AWS) -- an alliance of some 30 small right-wing parties clustered around the Solidarity union -- the Pope's May 31-June 10 visit is a gift from heaven which may translate into votes at the ballot box.
RIGHT EXPECTS BOOST FROM PAPAL VISIT
The rightist alliance has already printed large numbers of posters of the Pope, prominently stamped with its own logo.
The Pontiff, formerly Cardinal Karol Wojtyla, supported Solidarity during its struggle which led to the 1989 fall of communism and does not hide his sympathy for its traditions.

Solidarity identifies with Church interests. AWS demands that parliament ratify a concordat treaty with the Vatican, signed by a former government in 1993 to regulate the Church's status in Poland, but since delayed by leftists in parliament.
It also campaigns on a pledge to ban abortion, reversing a liberalisation of the law passed last year in a debate which divided Poles into roughly equal camps.
On this issue the Pope, who views abortion as killing, cannot keep silent even if his words help the political right.
"A nation which kills its own children is a nation without a future," he said last year after learning with distress that Poland was easing abortion on social grounds such as poverty.

"It is not the Pope's fault that in touching on such matters -- and I think he will refer to it -- he touches on politics. It is the fault of politicians who have politicised such ethical subjects," Pieronek said.
POLES SPLIT OVER ROLE OF CHURCH, RELIGION
The Church enjoyed great prestige before 1989 among Poles, 90 percent of whom are at least formally Catholics, because of its defence of human rights under communist rule.

But when pro-Catholic parties won power in democratic Poland, their moves to restore property and grant privileges to the Church aroused resentment, which was skillfully nurtured by the ex-communists to help their election victory in 1993.
Controversy on religious issues is intense now due to heated campaigning over a new constitution which Poles approved by about 53 percent to 47 percent in a referendum last Sunday.
The constitution, backed by the ruling coalition and two parliamentary opposition parties, leaves open the abortion issue and aims to include believers and non-believers alike.
Solidarity sought a "no" vote, proposing an alternative version clearly invoking God and effectively banning abortion.
Some Solidarity leaders asked bishops to seek God's help in defeating the constitution with a rare religious ceremony last performed when Bolshevik troops invaded Poland in 1920.
The bishops refused, saying God should not be asked to make political choices, but then strayed from neutrality and said the Church had clear moral reservations over the constitution.
"This is the latest defeat of the Catholic bishops who still cannot find a place for the Church in a democratic State," commented an ex-communist leader, Jerzy Szmajdzinski.

At the same time, progress towards clinching the concordat was again stalled this month by leftist deputies disputing details of bills that would pave the way for its ratification -- notably one allowing religious education in kindergartens.
These delays have undermined hopes the concordat would be approved by parliament during the Pope's visit.
POPE COULD HELP HEAL RIFTS

Leading centrist opposition figure Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a Catholic who helped to draft the new constitution and was pained by the Church's intervention, said the Pope's visit may serve to soothe divisions stirred up over religious issues.
"I think the Pope's visit will calm this atmosphere and pour oil on these troubled waters," Mazowiecki told Reuters.
Certainly, various key figures in Polish public life say they want an end to the use of religion in political rows.
Bishop Pieronek has argued that the Church should be apolitical and seek some co-existence with the ex-communists, who are now social democrats and may be in power for some time.
Ex-communist leaders including President Aleksander Kwasniewski say they wish to end feuds over the Church.
Kwasniewski, who visited the Pope in the Vatican earlier this year, said this month he hoped the Pontiff would bring the the same message he recently brought to Lebanon and Sarajevo.

"We need help in eliminating what could still be an obstacle or threat to us...the problem of understanding and unity between Poles on the most important matters," Kwasniewski told Wprost weekly in an interview.
On the right, in and outside Solidarity, there are voices calling for stress to be laid on other issues in campaigning.
RADICALS KEEP DIVISIONS ALIVE
But all sides include radicals eager to keep the pot boiling for ideological or tactical reasons.

The ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) has an anti-clericalist faction including several deputies linked with Poland's best-selling weekly magazine NIE (No), which carries vitriolic attacks on the Church and priests in each issue.

The Polish Church is hostage to Radio Maryja, a station run by an independent-minded priest whose audience of millions allows him to keep broadcasting a mixture of comforting prayer and strident ultra-nationalist, left-bashing commentary.
Numbers of individual bishops and prominent priests eagerly pronounce on political matters from the pulpit.
Despite concern over Radio Maryja's content, Pieronek says the Church cannot control it. The bishop himself has been attacked by rightist theologians for his liberalism.
For Poles, the Pope is perceived as above political rows, says Lena Kolarska-Bobinska, a sociologist and head of the Public Affairs Institute think-tank.
"The Pope is seen as an authority, not involved in political machinations, unlike the Polish Church," she said, adding that what he said might affect the political climate.
"If he speaks a lot on abortion he might strengthen these divisions, unless he speaks above the differences," she said.
